definition: A feature that automatically detects which chapter of the textbook a user is reading and uses that information to provide more relevant and contextually appropriate search results.
The process of automatically extracting chapter identification information from the current page using dual sources: URL pattern matching and DOM h1 heading extraction.

A three-level reliability indicator (high/medium/low) that indicates how confident the system is in its chapter detection. High confidence means both URL and DOM sources agree; medium means one source matches; low means neither source provided clear match.

The process of prioritizing search results that match the user's current chapter by applying a relevance boost multiplier (1.5x) to those results, causing chapter-specific content to rank higher in the search results.
A technique for increasing the search relevance score of results that match certain criteria (e.g., chapter matches, term frequency matches) by multiplying the original score by a boost factor.
A numerical multiplier applied to relevance scores to increase the ranking of matching results. For example, a 1.5x boost factor multiplies results by 1.5.

A text analysis technique that extracts important terms from selected text and applies a logarithmic relevance boost to search results containing those terms. Used in combination with chapter filtering to provide more precise search results.
A feature that allows users to select text from the page, which is then used to extract TF-IDF terms and boost search results containing those specific terms.

A specialized vector database used for semantic search. Stores text embeddings (1536-dimensional vectors) and metadata about textbook chapters and sections, enabling similarity-based search and filtering.

A search method that converts queries and documents into high-dimensional numerical vectors (embeddings) and finds similar documents by measuring distance between vectors using metrics like cosine similarity.

A numerical representation of text as a high-dimensional vector (array of numbers). In this system, text is converted to 1536-dimensional vectors using an embedding model, enabling semantic similarity searches.

An approach that combines document retrieval (using vector search) with large language model generation. The system retrieves relevant textbook sections, then generates an answer based on that retrieved context.

A design principle where features continue to work even if optional components fail. For example, chapter filtering is optional, so searches work normally if chapter detection fails or is unavailable.

The process of converting a human-readable chapter title (e.g., 'Inverse Kinematics') into a URL-safe identifier (e.g., 'inverse-kinematics') by lowercasing, removing special characters, and replacing spaces with hyphens.
Structured information about data. In this system, chapter filtering metadata includes whether filtering was applied, which chapter was used, boost factors, and result counts.
The documentation platform used to host the robotics textbook. Docusaurus generates static sites with URL patterns that the chapter detection system parses to identify chapters.
A browser API operation that searches the Document Object Model (DOM) for HTML elements. Used in chapter detection to find h1 headings containing chapter titles.
Using regular expressions to extract information from URL paths. In chapter detection, the pattern `/chapter[_-]?(\w+)/i` matches chapter identifiers in URLs.
A performance requirement defining maximum acceptable response time for an operation. For chapter context, the latency budget is <10ms for detection and <50ms for filtering.
Measurements of system behavior including latency (response time), throughput (operations per second), and resource usage. Tracked to ensure features meet performance budgets.
A programming practice where the system enforces correct data types at compile-time and runtime, preventing errors from type mismatches. Achieved using TypeScript on frontend and Pydantic on backend.
